Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Gastric Partitioning versus Gastrojejunostomy for Malignant Gastric Outlet Obstruction

Trial_Design.evidence: patients aged 18-85 with obstructive, unresectable distal gastric adenocarcinoma were randomised

Participants.evidence: patients aged 18-85 with obstructive, unresectable distal gastric adenocarcinoma were randomised

Objective.evidence: compared gastric partitioning with gastrojejunostomy for managing gastric outlet obstruction

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the acceptance of a full diet (GOOS 3) at discharge

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealed until after consent

Blinding.evidence: The trial was open-label, with no blinding of participants or clinicians

Number_Randomised.evidence: From August 2013 to April 2020, 90 patients were randomised: 46 to gastrojejunostomy and 44 to gastric partitioning

Number_Analysed.evidence: 25 in the gastrojejunostomy group and 27 in the partitioning group were analysed per-protocol

Result_Outcome.evidence: Acceptance of a normal diet was higher in the partitioning group (96% vs. 72%; p = 0.022)

Harms.evidence: The partitioning group had more frequent red blood cell transfusions (81% vs. 52%; p = 0.024)
